title: SPARTE
content:
SPARTE (Sparta) was the Naiad-nymph of the main spring, well or fountain of the town of Sparta in Lakedaimonia
        (southern Greece). She was a daughter of the river-god Eurotas and wife of the country's eponymous king
        Lakedaimon (Lacedaemon).

EUROTAS (Apollodorus 3.116, Pausanias
          8.25.2)

AMYKLAS, EURYDIKE (by Lakedaimon) (Apollodorus 3.116)

SPARTA (Sparta), a daughter of Eurotas by Clete, and wife of Lacedaemon, by whom she became the mother of
        Amyclas and Eurydice. (Apollod. iii. 10. ยง 3). From her the city of Sparta was believed to have derived its
        name (Paus. iii. 1. ยง 3; Schol. Eurip. Orest. 615). She was represented on a tripod at Amyclae.
        (Paus. iii. 18. ยง 5).

Source: Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology.

Pseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3. 116 (trans. Aldrich) (Greek mythographer C2nd
          A.D.) :
        "Lakedaimon (Lacedaemon) and Sparte (Sparta), a daughter of Eurotas--a son of autochthonous Lelex and a
        Naias Nymphe (Naiad Nymph) named Kleokhareia (Cleocharia)--were parents of Amyklas (Amyclas) and a daughter
        Eurydike (Eurydice) whom Akrisios (Acrisius) married."

Pausanias, Description of Greece 3. 1. 2 (trans. Jones) (Greek travelogue C2nd A.D.)
          :
        "Lakedaimon (Lacedaemon) was wedded to Sparta, a daughter of Eurotas. When he came to the throne, he first
        changed the name of the land and its inhabitants, calling them after himself, and next he founded and named
        after his wife a city, which even down to our day has been called Sparta."
